description:
Using developmental and systems frameworks and a family centered approach, the health and illness needs of children from birth through adolescence, and the related needs of their caregivers are addressed. The student is provided with a theory base, as well as opportunities for providing care to children with acute and chronic health problems, and their families. Using critical thinking, including the nursing process, strategies are developed for optimizing health; maintaining individuality; promoting optimal developmental, physiological, and psychological functioning; and, for enhancing strengths within the family unit. 

There are three primary foci for this course: taking care of sick children and families, child development, and professionalism.
name: NURSING OF CHILDREN: THEORY/CLINICAL

values.comments:
Nursing 220 uses developmental and systems frameworks and a family centered approach, the health and illness needs of children from birth through adolescence, and the related needs of their caregivers are addressed. The student is provided with a theory base, as well as opportunities for providing care to children with acute and chronic health problems, and their families. Using critical thinking, including the nursing process, strategies are developed for optimizing health, maintaining individuality, promoting optimal developmental, physiological, and psychological functioning, and for enhancing strengths within the family unit. There are three primary foci for this course: taking care of sick children and families, child development, and professionalism.

Students generally felt that this course was, overall, “very good.” They found it “well organized,” “stimulating,” and “informative.” However, some felt that the material was “too specific,” that the focus on case studies was “unsatisfying,” and that it was too “subjective.” Additionally, some students felt that the lectures were not helpful in understanding the material and that, compared to other Nursing courses, it felt as though it was “lacking direction.”

Many students expressed frustration that expectations “seemed to vary from instructor to instructor.” Additionally, some students disliked that there was “too much focus on case studies” and they felt they were unable to “apply it later.” Since much of the class utilized guest lecturers, some students felt that this lent some disorder to the process. However, many students liked the guest lecturers and the case study format, and they commented that “what [they] learned in class connected well to clinical.”

Many students were frustrated by the exams administered; they stated that the exams were very short and did not allow students to convey their knowledge. Many students also commented that the assigned reading felt “overwhelming” and that reading quizzes were “frustrating.” One student reported, “They told me that if I went to class and did the readings that I would be fine in the class. Despite the fact that I have done those things, I am struggling to get a B.” Some felt that the information tested was “nit-picky.” Students also complained that “expectations were not clear.” Prerequisites are NURS 104, 106, 131, and 132.

Many students also commented that the assigned reading felt “overwhelming” and that reading quizzes were “frustrating.” One student reported, “They told me that if I went to class and did the readings that I would be fine in the class. Despite the fact that I have done those things, I am struggling to get a B.” Some felt that the information tested was “nit-picky.” Students also complained that “expectations were not clear.” Prerequisites are NURS 104, 106, 131, and 132.

Nursing 220 addresses the use of developmental and systems frameworks and a family centered approach, the health and illness needs of children from birth through adolescence, and the related needs of their caregivers. The student is provided with a theory base, as well as opportunities for providing care to children with acute and chronic health problems, and their families. This class emphasizes critical thinking, including the nursing process; develops strategies for optimizing health, maintaining individuality, promoting optimal developmental, physiological, and psychological functioning, and for enhancing strengths within the family unit. There are three primary foci for this course: taking care of sick children and families, child development, and professionalism.

Students generally felt that the “modules [were] really time consuming. One student noted that the validation process was “very subjective and frustrating.” Some agreed that the “knowledge and skills” required of students was not clearly presented. Many felt that lab practice hours were helpful. Students generally wanted more emphasis on hands-on learning, as opposed to writing and responding to modules.

Overall, students felt that there was not enough communication between different instructors and there was “much variation” between lab instructors. Many commented that the professor’s instructions on Blackboard were very unclear. Most students did appreciate that the instructors made different lab times available for students who could not fit the original ones into their schedules. Students thought that passing or failing validation was “based on which validator” they had.

Regardless of the lack of organization, many students suggested that the lab seemed to teach material that was necessary for a “practicing nurse.” Students generally agreed that the validations were clearly not the best testing process. Students reported that the modules were not graded.
